topic.title: Beta 0: Installing HP Helion OpenStack on Baremetal

ul.li: Ensure the minimum hardware requirements are met.
All disks on the system(s) will be wiped: /dev/sda will be used for the OS but all other disks will be wiped.

The deployer node must run on HP Linux for HP Helion OpenStack. It is part of the ISO you will download from the Helion Downloads page. There is only one download; it includes both the OS and the Beta0 installer in one ISO.
Three NIC are tested, one 1G used for PXE and two bonded 10G for everything else. All machines can net boot from PXE and use the deployer as a DHCP server.
All machines of a single type should be the same, that is, all computes, all VSAs, and so on.
The deployer node must be a dedicated node in Beta0.

The machine hosting the deployer and all baremetal systems must be connected to a management network. Nodes on this management network must be able to reach the iLO subsystem of each baremetal system to enable host reboots as part of the install process. The HP Helion OpenStack architecture requires that the IPMI network is a separate network and that a route exists from the management network to the IPMI network for iLO access.

section.title: Before You Start
section.p: Prepare your baremetal hardware, as follows, on all nodes:

ul.li: Set up the iLO Advanced license in the iLO configuration.
Switch from UEFI to Legacy BIOS.
Ensure that the network to be used for PXE installation has PXE enabled.
Ensure that the other networks have PXE disabled.

section.title: Set up the Deployer

ol.li: Create LUN(s), if required.
Download the HP Helion OpenStack Deployer ISO from the Helion Downloads page after signing up and being approved for the program.
Boot your deployer from the ISO.
Enter "install" to start installation.
Select the language.
Select the location.
Select the keyboard layout.

Select the primary network interface, if prompted:
Assign IP address, netmask

Create new account:
Enter a username. It is best to leave the default here: stack.
Enter a password.
Enter time zone if prompted to do so.
Synchronize the time on all nodes manually. NTP will be installed later.

section.p: At the end of this section you should have a deployer node set up with hLinux on it.

section.title: Configure and Run the Deployer
section.note: Run as the user you just created (or stack if you left the default of "stack", but do not run as root.
Your NICs may have the wrong numbers/names assigned to them. If so, see the workaround in the release notes topic.

ol.li: On the deployer node, enter the following command to create the SSH keypair if one is not already present:ssh-keygen -t rsa
Add ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys file: cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys
Confirm that ssh localhost works without a password and that you can get from external sources, both with and without sudo.
Mount the install media at /media/cdrom, for example, sudo mount /media/cdrom
Unpack the following tarball: tar zxvf /media/cdrom/hos-2.0.0/hlm-deployer-2.0.0-20150805T115313Z.tgz
Run the following included script: ~/hlm-deployer/hlm-init-2.0.0.bash

section.p: At the end of this section you should have a local directory structure, as described below:
section.codeblock: helion/ Top level directory helion/examples/ Directory contains the config input files of the example clouds helion/my_cloud/definition/ Directory contains the config input files helion/my_cloud/config/ Directory contains .j2 files which are symlinks to the /hlm/ansible directory helion/hlm/ Directory contains files used by the installer

ol.li:
Set up your configuration files, as follows:
See the sample set of configuration files in the ~/helion/examples/one-region-poc-with-vsa directory. The accompanying README.md file explains the contents of each of the configuration files.
Copy the example configuration files into the required setup directory and edit them as required: cp -r ~/helion/examples/one-region-poc-with-vsa/* ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/ The configuration files for editing can be found at the following location: ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data
The baremetalConfig.yml file should specify the server information for your environment.
The servers.yml file contains the IP address information for the hardware.
The networks.yml file contains networking information.
The control_plane.yml file contains information about the services that will be installed.
In the net_interfaces.yml file, replace all instances of “bond-mode: 1” to “bond-mode: active-backup”.

Run the configuration processor, as follows: cd ~/helion/hlm/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run_v2.yml Note that if the installer tells you to run ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml, don't. Run command as above (v2).

Check the generated host files in ~/helion/my_cloud/stage/ansible/host_vars/ to ensure the correct IPs are included. If they are not, run ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-clean.yml and go to step 1.
Run the following command: export ANSIBLE_HOST_KEY_CHECKING=False
Run the following playbook: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml Note that the full path is <username>/helion/hlm/ansible/cobbler-deploy.yml
Run the following command, which will set all nodes to PXE boot and power cycle them to start their OS install:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-provision.yml

Wait for the nodes to install. They will power down at the end. You can make waiting easier with the following command:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-wait-for-shutdown.ymlThis will complete once all machines are down.
Once all nodes are down, power up the recently-installed systems, using the following command:ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-power-up.yml
You can make waiting easier with the command below, which will complete once all machines are up and the SSH daemon is responding: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-wait-for-ssh.yml

Run the following command: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-runV2.yml
Verify the network is working correctly by pinging each IP (excluding VSA-BLK and VIPs) from the deployer node. You can find the IP addresses in generated_files/etc/hosts. To do so, run:
~/helion/hlm/ansible$ less generated_files/etc/hosts

Edit roles/HZN-WEB/tasks/install.yml and add the following after the 'install-package' section: - name: HZN-WEB | install | TEMP fix horizon permissions sudo: yes command: "chown -R stack:stack {{ HORIZON_VENV_DIR }}/lib/python2.7/site-packages" the modified file should look as follows: # Install pre-packaged Horizon venv from tarball - name: HZN-WEB | install | Install Horizon install_package: name: horizon service: horizon state: present
- name: HZN-WEB | install | TEMP fix horizon permissions sudo: yes command: "chown -R stack:stack {{ HORIZON_VENV_DIR }}/lib/python2.7/site-packages"
Run the following command: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-deploy.yml -e tuning_selector=medium

Deploy VSA by running the following command: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts vsa-deploy.yml
If the output has the following error, manually upload the file to that location then rerun vsa-deploy:
stderr: tar: /opt/stack/service/vsa/venv/lib/helion-vsa-11.5.01.0079.tgz: Cannot open: No such file or directory
The file can be found at http://10.1.56.95/helion-vsa-11.5.01.0079.tgz
Note that you may need VPN access to downoad the file from the lab at the link above.
This is a temporary issue and should be fixed by the next release.

Deploy CMC by running the following command:
ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts cmc-deploy.yml

Note that the IP numbers of VSA VMs from ansible output appear as follows:
NIC 1: Virtual Network: vsa-network IP Address: 10.241.103.11 Subnet Mark: 255.255.255.0 Gateway: 10.241.103.1
Set your X display and launch CMC: ssh –X to the deployer node/opt/HP/StoreVirtual/UI/jre/bin/java -jar /opt/HP/StoreVirtual/UI/UI.jar
Manully add the IPs of those VMs.
Choose Tasks -> Management Group -> New Management Group from the menu above.
Enter the following name for the management group: hlm003-vsa-mg
Enter the following username and password: stack / stack
Add NTP servers. To get a list log in into any VSA node and type ntpq -pn.
Skip the DNS and SMTP sections.
Add the following cluster name: hlm003-vsa-cluster
Enter the VIP name, which you can find on the deployer in the following file: helion/my_cloud/stage/info/net_info.yml section cluster_ip.
Select the checkbox to skip volume creation.
Wait for completion.

Copy the VSA section (beginning with <unique section name, uncomment the lines under it, change the name of the section to [vsa-1], and fill the values as in the following example:
[vsa-1] hplefthand_password: stack hplefthand_clustername: hlm003-vsa-cluster hplefthand_api_url: https://10.241.103.7:8081/lhos hplefthand_username: stack hplefthand_iscsi_chap_enabled: true volume_backend_name: vsa-backend-hlm003 volume_driver: cinder.volume.drivers.san.hp.hp_lefthand_iscsi.HPLeftHandISCSIDriver hplefthand_debug: false
Note: Until Horizon is enabled, the volume_backend_name is not used.
Run the following command: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts cinder-reconfigure.yml
Create a volume to verify the VSA is correctly configured, then delete the created volume.

Note that running the command below will download a cirros image, upload a cirros image to Glance, and create a Neutron external network.ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-cloud-configure.ymlYou can optionally specify the external network CIDR here too. If you choose not to excercise this option or use a wrong value, the VMs will not be accessible over the network.ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-cloud-configure.yml -e EXT_NET_CIDR=10.240.96.0/20

Run the following command, which will replace /etc/hosts on the deployer: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cloud-client-setup.yml As etc/hosts no longer has entries for HLM, sudo commands may become a bit slower. To fix this issue, once this step is complete, in etc/hosts add "hlm" after "127.0.0.1 localhost". The result will look like this: ... # Localhost Information 127.0.0.1 localhost hlm
